title: Frances Lin
text:
I am a PhD candidate in Statistics at Oregon State University. I am currently a Software Engineer Intern at Posit Software, PBC (formerly RStudio Inc.).
Outside of work, I enjoy skiing, traveling, being outdoors, and watching thriller or dark comedy films and series on Netflix.

title: Hello, world!
text: Welcome to my new site, built with Quarto by Posit PBC. I’m currently in the process of migrating content from my previous site, so stay tuned!

title: Experience
text:
Oregon State University

Doctoral Researcher
Sep 2021 - Present


Statistics / ML Consultant
Jan 2021 - Mar 2025
• Provided consulting services across diverse fields, collaborating with faculty members, junior statisticians, and client researchers to support multiple PhD and master’s-level research initiatives.  • Effectively communicated statistical concepts to non-statistical clients and delivered in-depth reports on topics including simple statistical tests, advanced data modeling, application software (R, Python), experimental design, and data processing and visualization.


Graduate Teaching Assistant
Mar 2020 - Present
• Assist with graduate and undergraduate courses such as machine learning III, missing data and causal inference, spatial statistics, stochastic models, computational statistics, data analysis methods I (hypothesis testing, multiple testing), II (regression analysis, model selection), III (dimension reduction techniques, generalized regression models), mathematical statistics I, II, statistical methods, statistics for engineers, and elementary statistics I.  • Teach R programming and discuss statistical problems during labs or recitations, hold office hours, and grade exams and assignments.


Graduate Project Assistant
Jun 2024 - Aug 2024
• Assisted with the design and development of the course curriculum for spatial statistics.  • Applied a variety of spatial models, including kriging / Gaussian process regression, C / SAR (conditional / simultaneous autoregressive), and Poisson process / CSR models for simulation and applications such as housing price prediction, disease risk mapping, and forest and forest fire modeling.

title: About
text:
Thanks for visiting my site!
I am a PhD candidate in Statistics at Oregon State University. Broadly speaking, my research interests lie in
for large and complex time series data, with applications to energy forecasting and claims prediction. My other interests include deep learning and its more flexible and explainable probabilistic variant models (e.g., deep Gaussian processes, deep Gaussian Markov Random Fields) for space and space-time modeling.

title: About
text:
PhD
For my PhD dissertation, advised by Dr. Lisa Madsen and Dr. Charlotte Wickham (now at Posit Software, PBC), I focus on the Markov MTD (Mixture Transition Distribution) time series models and the Bayesian NNMP (Nearest-Neighbor Mixture Process) spatial models for time series forecasting and spatial prediction, as developed by Zheng et al. and presented in [1], [2], and [3]. To achieve robust, flexible, and scalable modeling of time series and spatial data, both the MTD and NNMP models utilize probabilistic graphical model (DAG or Bayesian network) representations, finite mixture model structures, Bayesian hierarchical model formations, and MCMC algorithms.
My specific contributions include incorporating the copulas in the MTD model to capture more complex and flexible dependence structures; extending the MTD model to handle zero-inflated positively-skewed data; validating the models and assessing model performance through simulations and real-world data applications; developing a software package for the proposed models (using R, C++); and comparing the proposed models with other benchmark approaches, such as LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks (using PyTorch), to ensure robustness and accuracy.

title: About
text:
Master’s
For my Master’s capstone project, advised by Dr. James Molyneux, I worked on selected spatial and temporal point processes leading up to Hawkes processes (or self-exciting point processes), which find applications in fields such as seismology, criminology, risk management, finance, etc.
